org.threadly.concurrent.limiter

Class SubmitterSchedulerLimiter

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.concurrent.limiter.SubmitterSchedulerLimiter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.concurrent.Executor, SimpleSchedulerInterface, SubmitterSchedulerInterface

    public class SubmitterSchedulerLimiter
extends java.lang.Object
implements SubmitterSchedulerInterface
    This class is designed to limit how much parallel execution happens on a provided SubmitterSchedulerInterface. This allows the implementor to have one thread pool for all their code, and if they want certain sections to have less levels of parallelism (possibly because those those sections would completely consume the global pool), they can wrap the executor in this class. Thus providing you better control on the absolute thread count and how much parallelism can occur in different sections of the program. Thus avoiding from having to create multiple thread pools, and also using threads more efficiently than multiple thread pools would.

      • SubmitterSchedulerLimiter

        public SubmitterSchedulerLimiter(SubmitterSchedulerInterface scheduler,
                         int maxConcurrency)
        Constructs a new limiter that implements the SubmitterSchedulerInterface.
        Parameters:
        scheduler - SubmitterSchedulerInterface implementation to submit task executions to.
        maxConcurrency - maximum qty of runnables to run in parallel

      • SubmitterSchedulerLimiter

        public SubmitterSchedulerLimiter(SubmitterSchedulerInterface scheduler,
                         int maxConcurrency,
                         java.lang.String subPoolName)
        Constructs a new limiter that implements the SubmitterSchedulerInterface.
        Parameters:
        scheduler - SubmitterSchedulerInterface implementation to submit task executions to.
        maxConcurrency - maximum qty of runnables to run in parallel
        subPoolName - name to describe threads while tasks running in pool (null to not change thread names)

      • submit

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<?> submit(java.lang.Runnable task)
        Description copied from interface: SubmitterSchedulerInterface
        Submit a task to run as soon as possible. There is a slight increase in load when using submit over execute. So this should only be used when the future is necessary. The future .get() method will return null once the runnable has completed.
        Specified by:
        submit in interface SubmitterSchedulerInterface
        Parameters:
        task - runnable to be executed
        Returns:
        a future to know when the task has completed
